Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The TEACH/Here Urban Teacher Residency program is offered through a partnership between the University of Tennessee, the Public Education Foundation, Hamilton County Schools (HCS), and Knox County Schools (KCS), with the goal of improving the learning and life outcomes of students by recruiting, preparing and supporting exceptional and effective mathematics and science teachers to teach in the districts' high-need schools through an alternative pathway. The program is providing 36 Teaching Fellows (in two cohorts) with course work and a focused yearlong residency program in two Learning Academy Schools in the partner districts. The program recruits outstanding college graduates who want to become teachers and have an academic background or work experience in a STEM field. As Teaching Fellows, the future teachers are paired with an outstanding mathematics or science teacher in a classroom for a full year, watching, learning, and experiencing how to be effective teachers. These pairs are further guided and supported by school-based master teachers. One day each week, the teaching fellows take classes to prepare them to assume responsibility for the classroom. The mentors and master teachers are provided professional development uniquely designed for them by the partners. At the end of the year, each teaching fellow earns a master's degree and a teaching license and is well-prepared to teach math or science in a high-need school, with ongoing coaching provided by the master teachers and mentors.

The approaches used by TEACH/Here to recruit, develop and retain mathematics and science teachers for hard-to-staff schools represent a collaborative effort that incorporates university teacher educators as well as content area faculty, two school systems, and an educational foundation that provides an outsider perspective and helpful critique. The harnessing of this strong partnership of groups to work collaboratively to offer a transformative program of teacher preparation is also expected to lead to development of a long-term capacity and commitment to teaching excellence in the partner districts. Information about the efficacy of the TEACH/Here Urban Teacher Residency programs is being disseminated statewide and beyond, so that the models can become a resource to others seeking to implement effective alternative teacher preparation programs for mathematics and science educators who are capable of succeeding in hard-to-staff schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
TEACH/Here set out to produce strong math and science teachers, leaders, and long-term professionals to educate students from diverse socioeconomic, racial, cultural and linguistic backgrounds. Teaching Fellows completed a residency program that UTK teacher education faculty developed around a full-year of clinical experience in secondary school settings. Prior to, during, after the residency year, Teaching Fellows took coursework designed prepare them for STEM teaching in urban STEM classrooms. Beyond the residency year, Teaching Fellows committed to four years of service as public school teachers in high-needs settings. To retain and support graduates of the program, we provided TEACH/Here Teaching Fellows with mentors and an ongoing Induction Program designed to be responsive to their content-driven needs, pedagogical needs, and emotional support needs.

Program partners collaborated in the selection of three cohorts of Teaching Fellows using an online application system for initial screening and a day-long group interview process for the final selection process. Through the selection process we  identified individuals who had strong content knowledge in math or science, and who desired to teach students in economically distressed communities. During the course of the cohort involvement, twenty-seven Teaching Fellows became licensed as math or science teachers. Of those twenty-seven, seventeen currently remain in the classroom. Three former Teaching Fellows are currently pursuing a Doctor of Philosophy degree in Teacher Education, thereby further expanding the lasting impact of the TEACH/Here project.

The TEACH/Here program offered induction support for teaching fellows for four years beyond the residency year. The goal was to provide support for teaching fellows as they began their professional careers teaching in high-needs secondary math and science classrooms. Retaining teachers and capitalizing on roles as leaders was priority during the induction support experience, providing teachers with several ongoing supports while developing their own paths for persevering through opportunities and challenges faced while teaching. Supports offered during the induction program included: monthly seminar meetings, group book studies, visits to see guest lecturers, support to attend professional development workshops and conferences, classroom visits by university and district personnel, and social/emotional support. Teaching Fellows claim part of their success was due to the comprehensive approach of the support, involving the total teaching experience.

Some of the comments from administrators:

“We see a difference in their preparedness. We see passionate, creative teachers who are open to sharing their practices.” LEA Administrator’s Comment

“Their content is strong. They are coachable and collaborative. They are innovative in their thinking. They are willing to do anything for kids. They have a drive/motivation/obligation to the profession. They are also willing to share.” ~Administrator’s Comment
